Fall 2018
EECS 149/249A:
Introduction to Embedded Systems
Instructors: Prabal Dutta and Sanjit A. Seshia
Format: 4 units, three hours of lecture, three hours of lab per week.
Overview: This course introduces students to the basics of models, analysis, and design
of software systems for distributed, wireless, and networked embedded systems to
support applications in the Internet-of-Things (IoT), Robotics, Smart Manufacturing, and
other areas. The course emphasizes a cyber-physical systems (CPS) perspective to
embedded systems: students learn how to combine physical processes with
computation, and how to coordinate distributed computing elements. The course has a
strong laboratory component, with emphasis on a semester-long sequence of projects.
If you’re a student who wants to learn how to program an autonomous vehicle, build an
Internet-connected sensor system, or develop a smart wearable, then EECS 149 is the
foundational design course for you.
Topics to be covered include the following:
1. Models of computation for cyber-physical systems: finite state machines, threads,
differential equations, hybrid systems, actors, discrete-events, data flow
2. Interfacing with the physical world: sensor/actuator modeling and calibration,
timing, concurrency in dealing with multiple real-time streams, handling numerical
imprecision in software
3. Embedded platforms: processors and memory architecture, real-time operating
systems, execution time analysis, scheduling, concurrency
4. Analysis and verification: Formal specification, systematic testing/simulation,
reachability analysis, model checking, controller synthesis, computer security.
5. Distributed systems and networking: Protocol design, wireless communications,
predictable networking, sensor networks.

years: http://chess.eecs.berkeley.edu/eecs149
